messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: anyone for a piece at auction
messages.msgSnippet: Jim, The work on the tsuba is very good but the shape seems so late, perhaps 1800-40, I m puzzled that I have never seen anything by Soten that would fill the
messages.messageBody:
Jim,
The work on the tsuba is very good but the shape seems so late, perhaps
1800-40, I'm puzzled that I have never seen anything by Soten that would
fill the gap between Soten II and this tsuba, a gap of maybe 50 or more
years. Do you agree?
Alan

----- Original Message -----
From: "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Sunday, November 16, 2003 11:26 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: anyone for a piece at auction


: Alan,
: I agree that it looks later than the time of the "real" Soten. I'll
speculate that the quality of the material and the workmanship were
sufficient for them to accept it as "of the school." I'll ask about it when
I get a chance.
:
: I happened to just look at this: http://www.nihonto.com/rh336.html and
http://www.nihonto.com/rh338.html
: where the kanteisho say mumei Hikone. But of course the shakudo one is
signed.
: Jim
:
:
:
: Matt, Jim,
: Thanks Matt, the figures and inlay are Soten style but the shape!!! I
did
: not think the Soten group worked as late as this tsuba appears to be, I
have
: not seen one like it before, ideas Jim?
: Alan
:
: [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
:
:

: nihontostudy-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: anyone for a piece at auction
messages.msgSnippet: Alan, I agree that it looks later than the time of the real Soten.  I ll speculate that the quality of the material and the workmanship were sufficient for
messages.messageBody:
Alan,
I agree that it looks later than the time of the "real" Soten. I'll speculate that the quality of the material and the workmanship were sufficient for them to accept it as "of the school." I'll ask about it when I get a chance.

I happened to just look at this: http://www.nihonto.com/rh336.html and http://www.nihonto.com/rh338.html
where the kanteisho say mumei Hikone. But of course the shakudo one is signed.
Jim



Matt, Jim,
Thanks Matt, the figures and inlay are Soten style but the shape!!! I did
not think the Soten group worked as late as this tsuba appears to be, I have
not seen one like it before, ideas Jim?
Alan

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: anyone for a piece at auction
messages.msgSnippet: Matt, Jim, Thanks Matt, the figures and inlay are Soten style but the shape!!! I did not think the Soten group worked as late as this tsuba appears to be, I
messages.messageBody:
Matt, Jim,
Thanks Matt, the figures and inlay are Soten style but the shape!!! I did
not think the Soten group worked as late as this tsuba appears to be, I have
not seen one like it before, ideas Jim?
Alan
----- Original Message -----
From: "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Friday, November 14, 2003 4:46 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: anyone for a piece at auction


: Alan,
: Thanks. Strange indeed.
:
: I don't have that catalog, can you post the image? I think I have already
seen the same thing elsewhere, though. Apparently pieces that are just "of
the school" can get Hozon kanteisho, but I don't know the specific criteria
used to separate these pieces from the run-of-the-mill late copies. If I
have the specific example I can follow up on it.
:
: Jim
:
:
:
: Jim, everybody,
: The mounting is strange, the fittings are very old, the kurikata and
fuchi
: are made of thin metal with the nanako almost worn away, the inlay looks
: like uttori with a 'trench' around each piece but the gold is not worn
as I
: would expect, you can easily tell uttori when you can see the gaps in
the
: gold inlay, this inlay is perfect. One thought I have is that the
kashira
: was originally the kojiri, I feel the shape would make more sense this
way.
: Altogether a puzzling item. There is no bare wood visible.
: Regarding another tsuba, if you have Sotheby's London catalogue of 11
: November lot 27 is a Soten tsuba with a Hozon paper, the item is clearly
: 19th century and a long time after the 2nd Soten, any ideas?
: Alan
:
:
:

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: anyone for a piece at auction
messages.msgSnippet: Alan, Thanks.  Strange indeed. I don t have that catalog, can you post the image?  I think I have already seen the same thing elsewhere, though.  Apparently
messages.messageBody:
Alan,
Thanks. Strange indeed.

I don't have that catalog, can you post the image? I think I have already seen the same thing elsewhere, though. Apparently pieces that are just "of the school" can get Hozon kanteisho, but I don't know the specific criteria used to separate these pieces from the run-of-the-mill late copies. If I have the specific example I can follow up on it.

Jim



Jim, everybody,
The mounting is strange, the fittings are very old, the kurikata and fuchi
are made of thin metal with the nanako almost worn away, the inlay looks
like uttori with a 'trench' around each piece but the gold is not worn as I
would expect, you can easily tell uttori when you can see the gaps in the
gold inlay, this inlay is perfect. One thought I have is that the kashira
was originally the kojiri, I feel the shape would make more sense this way.
Altogether a puzzling item. There is no bare wood visible.
Regarding another tsuba, if you have Sotheby's London catalogue of 11
November lot 27 is a Soten tsuba with a Hozon paper, the item is clearly
19th century and a long time after the 2nd Soten, any ideas?
Alan



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.messageBody:
Jim, everybody,
The mounting is strange, the fittings are very old, the kurikata and fuchi
are made of thin metal with the nanako almost worn away, the inlay looks
like uttori with a 'trench' around each piece but the gold is not worn as I
would expect, you can easily tell uttori when you can see the gaps in the
gold inlay, this inlay is perfect. One thought I have is that the kashira
was originally the kojiri, I feel the shape would make more sense this way.
Altogether a puzzling item. There is no bare wood visible.
Regarding another tsuba, if you have Sotheby's London catalogue of 11
November lot 27 is a Soten tsuba with a Hozon paper, the item is clearly
19th century and a long time after the 2nd Soten, any ideas?
Alan



----- Original Message -----
From: "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Thursday, November 13, 2003 12:56 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: anyone for a piece at auction


: Ray,
: I think that it's a legitimate Japanese koshirae, although the bare wood
parts are apparently replacements to fill in the "blanks." It'd be hard to
cobble together something with such an unusual shape to the saya, tsuka and
kashira. The shape and the suspension ring remind me of toppei koshirae
from Bakumatsu. The catalog entry claims that the fittings are decorated in
uttori, which if correct would suggest a much earlier date. I can't tell
from the photo whether the ring might be a later modification. Without
having seen it in person all I can do is speculate. It's unusual enough
that even after seeing it I wouldn't be surprised if I was still stuck.
:
: Alan (or anyone else who might have seen it (or now owns it)), any ideas?
This is the lot illustrated as 253, but described under 251.
:
: Jim
:
:
:
: Hi Jim, thanks for the background. If not Ainu, I am very curious
: what the origin of a koshirae like this would be. Perhaps someone
: simply cobbled this together from the fragments of other koshirae?
: Or, maybe this piece originated outside of Japan. I am sure it would
: be instructive to see the blade...
:
: - Ray
:
:

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: anyone for a piece at auction
messages.msgSnippet: Ray, I think that it s a legitimate Japanese koshirae, although the bare wood parts are apparently replacements to fill in the blanks.  It d be hard to
messages.messageBody:
Ray,
I think that it's a legitimate Japanese koshirae, although the bare wood parts are apparently replacements to fill in the "blanks." It'd be hard to cobble together something with such an unusual shape to the saya, tsuka and kashira. The shape and the suspension ring remind me of toppei koshirae from Bakumatsu. The catalog entry claims that the fittings are decorated in uttori, which if correct would suggest a much earlier date. I can't tell from the photo whether the ring might be a later modification. Without having seen it in person all I can do is speculate. It's unusual enough that even after seeing it I wouldn't be surprised if I was still stuck.

Alan (or anyone else who might have seen it (or now owns it)), any ideas? This is the lot illustrated as 253, but described under 251.

Jim



Hi Jim, thanks for the background. If not Ainu, I am very curious
what the origin of a koshirae like this would be. Perhaps someone
simply cobbled this together from the fragments of other koshirae?
Or, maybe this piece originated outside of Japan. I am sure it would
be instructive to see the blade...

- Ray


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

be instructive to see the blade...

- Ray

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: anyone for a piece at auction
messages.msgSnippet: Ray, I have been looking back and forth at my catalog and the site, which has gotten me confused.  The description of lots 253 and 251 appear to be reversed.
messages.messageBody:
Ray,
I have been looking back and forth at my catalog and the site, which has gotten me confused. The description of lots 253 and 251 appear to be reversed. The blade signed Kanenaga is actually in the very un-Ezo koshirae labeled 253. That is the koshirae you linked to and it is correctly described under lot 251. It's quite an unusual piece, but Ezo it is not.

Since I already got into writing this, the term Ezo has been used in a couple of ways and can be confusing. Strictly in terms of kodogu and koshirae it is usually applied today to examples like lots 225, 230 and 251/253. There doesn't seem to be any evidence associating these kind of fittings with the Ainu. We can talk some more about that type of kodogu if anyone is interested. I am at least.

Another more common use of the term Ezo is associated with the Ainu, and there is a very distinctive type of Ainu koshirae that is usually made up of some typical "Japanese" metal fittings mixed with uniquely Ainu type saya, tsuka and sash. Again, something for further discussion if anyone wants.

The metal fittings of the lot you linked to are not what I think of as either Ezo or Ainu, in any usual usage. The little loop fitting makes me think of a late toppei koshirae (the type made for wear with Western dress). The saya decoration is very unusual, as is the kashira shape. The tsuba and kojiri seem to be fillers. It's a koshirae that I'd like to look into more.

Let me know if you have more questions, since this is pretty mixed up.
Jim


Jim, the Ezo koshirae is very interesting to me too. Can you give
some background on group? I had been under the misimpression that
these pieces were Ainu...

http://www.christies.com/LotFinder/search/alt_images.asp?
lObjectID=4179742

Thanks,
Ray


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
